steps.prompt:
You will generate code for a rails application, specifically in the area of setting up new models, I will give you a table name, schema and list of what I want you to create.

Table Name: [table_name]

Schema:
[schema]

Can you create command line calls to generate model, factory and unit test.
Can you follow rails, rspec or factory_bot best practices when generating code.

---

Here are multiple examples

EXAMPLE 1

Table Name: Workflow
Schema:

| Field        | Type    | Description                         | Validation               |
|--------------|---------|-------------------------------------|--------------------------|
| id           | integer | Primary key, auto-incremented       |                          |
| name         | string  | The name of the workflow            | Must be present          |
| description  | string  | A brief description of the workflow |                          |

Command line calls:

rails generate model Workflow name:string description:string
rake db:migrate && rake db:migrate RAILS_ENV=test
rails generate rspec:model Workflow

Sample code for model:

# frozen_string_literal: true

class Workflow < ApplicationRecord
  validates :name, presence: true
end

Sample code for factory

# frozen_string_literal: true

FactoryBot.define do
  factory :workflow do
    name { 'Test Workflow' }
    description { 'A test workflow' }
  end
end

# frozen_string_literal: true

Sample unit test

# frozen_string_literal: true

RSpec.describe Workflow, type: :model do
  # Basic validations using FactoryBot
  it 'is valid with valid attributes' do
    workflow = FactoryBot.build(:workflow)
    expect(workflow).to be_valid
  end

  it 'is not valid without a name' do
    workflow = FactoryBot.build(:workflow, name: nil)
    expect(workflow).not_to be_valid
  end
end

EXAMPLE 2

Table Name: sections

| Field       | Type    | Description                            | Requirements                          |
|-------------|---------|----------------------------------------|---------------------------------------|
| id          | integer | Primary key, auto-incremented          |                                       |
| workflow_id | string  | Foreign key referencing workflows      | Must be present                       |
| name        | string  | The name of the section                | Must be present                       |
| description | string  | A brief description of the section     |                                       |
| order       | integer | The order of the section in the workflow| Must be present and a positive integer|

Command line calls:

rails generate model Section workflow_id:string name:string description:string order:integer
rake db:migrate && rake db:migrate RAILS_ENV=test
rails generate rspec:model Section

Sample code for model:

# frozen_string_literal: true

class Section < ApplicationRecord
  belongs_to :workflow
  
  validates :name, presence: true
  validates :order, presence: true, numericality: { only_integer: true, greater_than: 0 }
end

Sample code for factory:

# frozen_string_literal: true

FactoryBot.define do
  factory :section do
    association :workflow
    name { 'Test Section' }
    description { 'A test section description' }
    order { 1 }
  end
end

Sample unit test:

# frozen_string_literal: true

RSpec.describe Section, type: :model do
  # Validations
  it { should validate_presence_of(:name) }
  it { should validate_presence_of(:order) }
  it { should validate_numericality_of(:order).only_integer.is_greater_than(0) }

  # Associations
  it { should belong_to(:workflow) }

  # Factory test
  it 'has a valid factory' do
    expect(FactoryBot.build(:section)).to be_valid
  end
end

EXAMPLE 3

### Table: prompts

| Field          | Type    | Description                                         | Validation                       |default|
|----------------|---------|-----------------------------------------------------|----------------------------------|-|
| id             | integer | Primary key, auto-incremented                       |                                  | |
| workflow_id    | integer | Foreign key referencing workflows                   |                                  | |
| name           | string  | The name of the prompt                              | Must be present                  | |
| path           | string  | A path or reference to where the prompt is stored   |                                  | |
| content        | text    | The content of the prompt                           |                                  | |
| description    | string  | A brief description of the prompt’s purpose         |                                  | |
| tags           | enum    | Tags to classify the prompt (e.g., 'primary', 'partial', 'system') | Must be present | 'primary' |
| metadata       | jsonb   | Metadata associated with the prompt (key-value pairs)|                                  | |

Command line calls:

rails generate model Prompt workflow:references name:string content:text description:string tags:integer metadata:jsonb
rake db:migrate && rake db:migrate RAILS_ENV=test
rails generate rspec:model Prompt

Sample migration file:

class CreatePrompts < ActiveRecord::Migration[7.1]
  def change
    create_table :prompts do |t|
      t.references :workflow, null: false, foreign_key: true
      t.string :name, null: false
      t.string :path
      t.text :content
      t.string :description
      t.integer :tags, null: false, default: 0 # Tags as enum, defaulting to 'primary'
      t.jsonb :metadata

      t.timestamps
    end
  end
end

Sample code for model:

# frozen_string_literal: true

class Prompt < ApplicationRecord
  belongs_to :workflow

  enum tags: { primary: 0, partial: 1, system: 2 }, default: :primary

  validates :name, presence: true
  validates :tags, presence: true
end

Sample code for factory:

# frozen_string_literal: true

FactoryBot.define do
  factory :prompt do
    association :workflow
    name { 'Test Prompt' }
    path { 'path/to/prompt' }
    content { 'This is a test prompt content.' }
    description { 'A test prompt description' }
    tags { :primary }
    metadata { { example_key: 'example_value' } }
  end
end

Sample unit test:

# frozen_string_literal: true

RSpec.describe Prompt, type: :model do
  # Validations
  it { should validate_presence_of(:name) }
  it { should validate_presence_of(:tags) }

  # Associations
  it { should belong_to(:workflow) }

  # Enum
  it { should define_enum_for(:tags).with_values(%i[primary partial system]) }

  # Factory test
  it 'has a valid factory' do
    expect(FactoryBot.build(:prompt)).to be_valid
  end
end

GENEAL GUIDELINES and OVERRIDES

Migration Generation Guidelines:

Standard protocol is just to write a `generate model` command
If you encounter column type enum then use integer as data type
If you see a default field value then give a hint in the form of code of how the migration file should look with comments.


Model Generation Guidelines:

If a field has a default value then we define in the Rails Model.
If a field type is enum then add the enum DSL method into the model
If a field is boolean and must be present then validates shouild like 'validates :file_name_goes_here, inclusion: { in: [true, false] }'

Unit Test Code Generation Guidelines:

Use Factory Bot to create test data, especially in the model layer, as it keeps setup concise and reusable; prefer this over mocks or doubles.
Prefer one-liner tests for simple validations or method checks using `is_expected.to` or `expect(subject).to`.
Use `describe` to group tests by method or class, and `context` to describe different conditions or states within those tests.
Use test doubles, mocks, and stubs to isolate the unit being tested by replacing dependencies with simplified versions.
Use `let` for lazy evaluation of test data and `let!` when immediate evaluation is needed to keep test setup efficient.
Utilize `before` hooks for setting up data or state before each test and `after` hooks for cleanup when necessary.
We are also using `shoulda-matchers` to handle basic model validations. **Ensure that you are using `shoulda-matchers` for validating presence, numericality, and associations instead of writing manual validation tests.** This keeps our test suite concise and leverages the full power of `shoulda-matchers` to avoid redundancy.
`require 'rails_helper'` is redundant, as it is automatically included in our test environment setup.
Write a test for enum if a column type is enum
If a field is boolean then and must be present then, do not write a validation test as it cannot be trusted
